topics.body: "I just ran":http://gifsound.com/?gif=https://derpicdn.net/img/view/2014/2/16/553992__safe_solo_fluttershy_animated_running_flash_artist-colon-hydrusbeta.gif&v=vRuoI_ntlVI

topics.body:
"@ThatRandomGuy42":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/539f54de6368726cb3790000#post_539f54de6368726cb3790000
"@twistedmetalero":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/539f556d6368726be8780000#post_539f556d6368726be8780000
In all seriousness, I've been in this situation (and in fewer and fewer ways, still am).  What I've found is that when you're at the point where you start thinking about yourself and what you lack too much, that's generally when it's the perfect time to go think about and do stuff for others.  Even if they never say or give gratitude, you'll start to get happier as they get happier, and you'll start to feel like you're belonging more and more.
It's a very slow process - I'm still trying to come to complete terms that I can help others and even at least get them to smile despite them never saying anything, but I'm getting it.
Point is, I can guarantee - at least from my perspective - that things will get better.  Sometimes a show of recognition or gratitude or someone laughing at your joke is all you need to keep going.  And if those signs don't appear, just hang on and keep at it, without smothering others' legitimate feelings and actively helping them out.
topics.author: 4fde0c7e945b706cc30003eb
